abstract.p: Thomas D Bratter letter on Bernard Weinraub's June 11 column recalling golden age of musical theater in California; recalls productions at Civic Light Operas in both northern and southern California (S)

block.p: ''Shhh. There's a New Musical. It's Hush-Hush'' by Bernard Weinraub [June 11] recalls the golden age of musical theater in California, when Edwin Lester's Los Angeles and San Francisco Civic Light Operas would sell out the old Philharmonic Auditorium down here and the Curran Theater up there with glorious revivals, original Broadway casts imported directly from their New York runs (complete with the costumes, the scenery, the makeup, the props) and such original creations as ''Song of Norway,'' ''Kismet'' and ''Peter Pan.''

''Shhh. There's a New Musical. It's Hush-Hush'' by Bernard Weinraub [June 11] recalls the golden age of musical theater in California, when Edwin Lester's Los Angeles and San Francisco Civic Light Operas would sell out the old Philharmonic Auditorium down here and the Curran Theater up there with glorious revivals, original Broadway casts imported directly from their New York runs (complete with the costumes, the scenery, the makeup, the props) and such original creations as ''Song of Norway,'' ''Kismet'' and ''Peter Pan.''

The C.L.O.'s inspired local companies, often calling themselves Civic Light Operas, in both Northern and Southern California. Two of the more notable were the Starlight Opera in San Diego and the Sacramento Music Circus, which itself inspired a host of imitators, including musicals in the round in the Garden Court of San Francisco's Palace Hotel, the Circle Star Theater down the Peninsula, the Valley Music Theater in the San Fernando Valley and Melodyland in Anaheim.

Jack O'Brien of the Old Globe should have visited San Diego 40 or 50 years ago. He would have found theater thriving, with the La Jolla Playhouse, the old Old Globe and the Starlight rivaling the San Diego Zoo as tourist attractions.
